clips.Title: Signature
clips.Goal: Signature audio clips give the audience an immediate understanding of some element of the story.
clips.Description: A good signature audio clip grabs the audience and intrigues them to listen further.
clips.Tip: You may need to keep your mic very close to record a signature clip. Check that your source audio is not too loud.

clips.Title: Ambient
clips.Goal: Help the audience understand the space the subject inhabits.
clips.Description: Ambient audio clips help the audience understand how your subject interacts with the surrounding environment.
clips.Tip: You want the ambient clip to contribute to telling the story. If there are irrelevant sounds to the story this may distract the audience.

clips.Title: Narrative
clips.Goal: Record the character making an introduction, or record yourself introducing the character.
clips.Description: Tell the audience who is the important character in the story.
clips.Tip: Keep this clip brief. Simply introduce the audience to the character, or allow the character to introduce herself. Save additional information for the interview.

clips.Title: Interview
clips.Goal: Ask the character to tell you a story.
clips.Description: Remember the fundamentals of a good interview. Ask open-ended questions. Decide your questions based on the type of source you are interviewing.
clips.Tip: If you want the audience to hear your questions and the subjectâ€™s answers, be sure that you are both close enough to the mic to be heard clearly.

clips.Title: Environmental
clips.Goal: Environmental audio clips help the audience understand where your story takes place.
clips.Description: Environmental audio may indicate the country or add a cultural or religious element to your story.
clips.Tip: Record the overall sound for the environment. Be sure not to make any noise yourself, this will distract the audience from the natural sound.
